choices.text: Dorsolateral migration of neural crest cells
Migration of cells from paraxial mesoderm

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency department with complaints of pain in the anterolateral aspect of thigh. Physical examination revealed a swollen, tender right thigh anteriorly. Extension of the knee was limited due to pain. Ultrasonography of the area revealed a defect in the fibres of the quadriceps muscle, confirmed by CT scan of the limb. Which of the following is the embryologic origin of the affected structure?
questions.solution:
• The muscles of the limbs develop from the myotome component of the somites.
  • The somites are condensations of paraxial mesoderm that form after the formation of the trilaminar disc.

Somites form from the paraxial portion of the mesodermal germ layer. They first appear as segmental blocks of loosely organized mesoderm (somitomeres) along the axis of the embryo. The cells then undergo an epithelialization process to form somites that consist of a ventral portion, the sclerotome, and a dorsal portion that has two types of cells: the dermatome (central part) and myotome (medial and lateral parts). Cells in the myotome regions proliferate and migrate beneath the dermatome to form the dermomyotome.

Eventually, all the cells in the somite lose their epithelial characteristics and become mesenchymal again. Sclerotome cells migrate to form the vertebrae and ribs, myotomes form skeletal muscle, and the dermatomes form the dermis of the back.

Cross section through the somites and neural tube showing the organization of the paraxial mesoderm into somites and intermediate and lateral plate mesoderm.

Other Options

A. Lateral plate mesoderm

  • The lateral plate mesoderm gives rise to the serous membranes, coverings of organs and the heart.

B. Dorsolateral migration of neural crest cells

  • Neural crest cells give rise to dorsal root ganglia, leptomeninges, Schwann cells, sympathetic ganglia, and the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.

D. Intermediate mesoderm

  • The intermediate mesoderm gives rise to the urogenital system and its accessory glands

choices.text: Loss of sensation over hypothenar muscles
Loss of sensation over dorsum of little fingertip
Loss of sensation on nail of index finger
Loss of sensation on 4th interdigital cleft

questions.text: Injury to marked nerve can cause.
questions.solution:
The marked nerve is median nerve.

Injury to median nerve leads to loss of sensation in the index finger.

Sensory innervation of hand

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage.
questions.solution:
Elastic cartilage is a type of cartilage that has the following histological features:

  • Elastic fibers-Elastic cartilage is made up of a network of elastic fibers that are embedded in the ground substance. These fibers are visible under a microscope when stained with special stains, such as Verhoeff van Geison, aldehyde fuchsin, Weigert's elastic, or orcein.
  • Chondrocytes - Chondrocytes are cells that lie in lacunae, or spaces, between the elastic fibers. They make up only about 2% of the tissue's volume.
  • Perichondrium - Elastic cartilage is surrounded by a layer of dense irregular connective tissue called the perichondrium. The perichondrium has two layers: the outer fibrous layer and the inner chondrogenic layer.
  • Matrix - The matrix of elastic cartilage is made up of elastic fibers, type II collagen, glycosaminoglycans, proteoglycans, and multiadhesive glycoproteins.
  • Appearance - When stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), elastic cartilage appears similar to hyaline cartilage because the elastic fibres are unstained.

Types of Cartilage

questions.text: Identify the arrow marked structure in the histological image.
questions.solution:
Purkinje cell bodies are shaped like a flask and have many threadlike extensions called dendrites, which receive impulses from other neurons called granule cells. Each cell also has a single projection called an axon, which transmits impulses to the part of the brain that controls movement, the cerebellum.

Purkinje cells are a unique type of neuron-specific to the cerebellar cortex. They are remarkable for their massive, intricately branched, flat dendritic trees, which give them the ability to integrate large amounts of information and learn by remodeling their dendrites.

Cerebellar cortex

questions.text: Left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a comparatively longer course due to the persistence of which pharyngeal artery.
questions.solution: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is longer than the right RLN because of the persistence of the left sixth arch artery, which becomes the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text:
Arrange the following cells in basal to luminal side order?

1. Spermatogonium
2. Spermatozoa
3. Primary spermatocyte
4. Spermatid
5. Myofibroblast

Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.solution:
Outside to inside/basal to luminal:

Other options

Option A - Spermatozoa is present at most luminal side and not just after myofibril.

Option C - Spermatogonium is never interior to primary spermatocyte. So incorrect.

Option D - Myofibril is present outside spermatogonium.

choices.text: Perineal branch of fourth sacral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is not the content of Ischiorectal fossa.
questions.solution:
Contents of Ischiorectal Fossa

  • Ischiorectal pad of fat.
  • Inferior rectal nerves and vessels (running from lateral to medial side).
  • Perineal branch of fourth sacral nerve enters the posterior angle of the fossa running over levator ani to reach sphincter ani externus which it innervates.
  • Posterior scrotal (or labial) nerves and vessels cross the anterolateral part of the fossa to enter the urogenital triangle.

Contents of the ischiorectal fossa

Other Options:

Option A. Inferior rectal nerve

  • Inferior rectal nerves and vessels are content of Ischiorectal fossa.

Option B. Posterior scrotal nerve

  • Posterior scrotal (or labial) nerves and vessels cross the anterolateral part of the ischiorectal fossa to enter the urogenital triangle.

Option C. Perineal branch of fourth sacral nerve

  • Perineal branch of fourth sacral nerve enters the posterior angle of the ischiorectal fossa running over levator ani to reach sphincter ani externus which it innervates.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is admitted to the hospital from the emergency department because of severe pain in the back and left shoulder. A CT scan reveals an abscess in the upper part of the left kidney, but no abnormality is detected in the shoulder region. The shoulder pain may be caused by the spread of the inflammation to which of the following neighbouring structures?
questions.solution:
The abscess may have spread to the diaphragm,  because the diaphragm lies in close proximity to the superior poles of the kidneys. The diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerves, bilaterally, which descend to the diaphragm from spinal nerve levels C3, C4, and C5. It is probably at the spinal cord that the referral of pain occurs between the phrenic nerve and somatic afferents entering at those levels.

Renal transplantation: Left kidney transplantation is preferred (due to longer renal vein). The donor kidney is placed retroperitoneally in the iliac fossa with hilum parallel to the external iliac vessels. The renal artery is anastomosed end to end to the internal iliac artery and renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external iliac vein. The ureter is implanted into the urinary bladder (ureterocystostomy).

Other Options:

Option A. Descending colon

  • The descending colon is innervated by parasympathetic nerves from S2 to S4.

Option C. Duodenum

  • The duodenum is innervated by the vagus nerve.

Option D. Liver

  • The liver is innervated sympathetically from the celiac ganglion; the parasympathetic nerves to the liver are by the vagus nerve. Neither of these two sources of innervation enters the spinal cord at the level of the shoulder and therefore could not cause referred pain to the shoulder.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency department with a severe swelling on the right side of her neck. An MRI examination reveals an abscess. The abscess is surgically removed from the middle of the posterior cervical triangle on the right side. During recovery the patient notices that her shoulder droops and she can no longer raise her right hand above her head to brush her hair. Which of the following nerves has most likely been iatrogenic ally injured?
questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve passes across the posterior triangle of the neck and innervates both the trapezius muscle and the sternocleidomastoid muscle for the respective side of the body. Upon surgical division of the nerve, the patient will lose the ability to raise the ipsilateral shoulder and will demonstrate weakness in turning the head to the opposite side. The trapezius will also lose tone and the shoulder will droop.

Contents of the posterior triangle

Other Options:

B. Ansa cervicalis

  • The ansa cervicalis innervates strap muscles of the neck and, if cut, would not produce drooping of the shoulder.

C. Facial

  • The facial nerve does not pass through any of the triangles of the neck; however, if it were divided, paralysis would result in the muscles of facial expression.

D. Hypoglossal

  • The hypoglossal nerve innervates the intrinsic muscles of the tongue, plus the genioglossus, hyoglossus, and styloglossus and, if injured, would not result in any of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with sharp pain in the left lower quadrant. Patient history reveals that her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals a ruptured ovarian cyst on the left side The sonogram also reveals approximately 90 mL of fluid in the pelvis, which is presumed to represent cyst contents and bleeding from the rupture site. Where is this fluid most likely located?
questions.solution:
The most likely location of fluid to accumulate is the rectouterine pouch (of Douglas) because it is the lowest point in the pelvis when a patient is standing erect. Additionally, fluid would accumulate here because the mesovarian ligament causes the ovary to be located on the posterior aspect of the board ligament. This allows for communication between the fluid of the ovary and the rectouterine pouch.

Left view of a sagittal section through the rectouterine pouch

Rectouterine Pouch (Pouch of Douglas)

This is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity when the body is in the upright position. In the supine position, it is the most dependent part of the pelvic cavity.

Morrison's or hepatorenal pouch with rectouterine or Douglas pouch.

Other Options

A. Right subphrenic space

  • The right subphrenic space is located inferior to the right side of the diaphragm and superior to the liver.

B. Paracolic gutters

  • The paracolic gutters are located lateral to the ascending and descending colons. Neither of these locations is a likely site of fluid accumulation when the patient is standing

C. Vesicouterine pouch

  • The vesicouterine pouch is located between the bladder and uterus and is separated from the ovaries by a double layer of mesentery also known as the broad ligament of the uterus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the neurosurgical clinic for a scheduled removal of a tumor in the left jugular canal. Postoperatively, the patient has no gag reflex when the ipsilateral pharyngeal wall is stimulated, although the pharynx moved upward and a gag reflex resulted when the right pharyngeal wall was stimulated. The uvula was deviated to the right and the left vocal cord had drifted toward the midline. Which of the following structures will contain the neural cell bodies for the motor supply of the paralyzed muscles?
questions.solution:
The nucleus ambiguus gives rise to efferent motor fibers of the vagus nerve, which supply the laryngeal and pharyngeal muscles. If supply to this region is interrupted, an individual loses the swallowing, cough, and gag reflexes.

The nucleus ambiguus lies in the medulla. It forms an elongated column lying in both the open and closed parts of the medulla.

It supplies:

a. The stylopharyngeus muscle through the glossopharyngeal nerve; and

b. The muscles of the soft palate, the pharynx and the larynx through the vagus nerve and the cranial part of the accessory nerve.

Other Options

A . Nucleus solitarius

  • The nucleus solitarius is located in the brainstem and is responsible for receiving general visceral sensation and taste from the facial, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves.

B. Trigeminal motor nucleus

  • The trigeminal motor nucleus contains motor neurons that innervate muscles of mastication, the tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, mylohyoid, and anterior belly of the digastric.

C. Dorsal motor nucleus

  • The dorsal motor nucleus contains the cell bodies of preganglionic parasympathetic fibers of the vagus nerve innervating the heart muscle and smooth musculature and glands of the respiratory and intestinal tract.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is admitted to the hospital complaining of diplopia (double vision) when walking down stairs. During physical examination of the extraocular muscles the patient experiences diplopia, and when he is asked to turn his right eye inward toward his nose and look down, he is able to look inward but not down. Which of the following nerve is most likely involved according to the image given below.
questions.solution:
• B marked structure is Trochlear nerve.
  • The superior oblique muscle turns the pupil downward from the adducted position.
  • Inability to perform this motion, in conjunction with diplopia when walking down stairs, indicates damage to the trochlear nerve

When trochlear nerve is damaged, diplopia occurs on looking downwards; vision is single so long as the eyes look above the horizontal plane.

Paralysis of the trochlear nerve results in:

  1. Defective depression of the adducted eye.
  2. Diplopia.

Other options

A . A

  • A marked structure is olfactory nerve, and when it is injured it leads to
    • Anosmia- loss of sense of smell
    • Hyposmia- decrease ability to detect smell
    • Hyperosmia- increased sensitivity to the sense of smell

C . C

  • C marked structure is Optic nerve
  • Traumatic optic neuropathy(TON) is a serious vision threatening condition that can be caused by ocular or head trauma.

D . D

  • D marked structure is Oculomotor nerve
  • The oculomotor nerve supplies the superior, inferior, and medial rectus as well as the inferior oblique.
  • Overall, innervation from the oculomotor nerve results in upward and inward movements of the eye, and a lesion of this nerve would not induce diplopia in an individual walking down stairs

questions.text: Nerve supply of the muscle shown in diagram.
questions.solution:
The muscle shown in image is levator scapulae .

Innervation

The levator scapulae is innervated by 2-3 branches of the 3rd and 4th cervical nerves, and frequently by a branch from the dorsal scapular nerve.

choices.text: Failure of rostral neuropore to close
Failure of neural crest migration into the first arch

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to a plastic surgeon's office. He has a small jaw, large mouth, flat cheek- bones, and malformed pinna. He had a cleft palate at birth, which was surgically corrected shortly afterward. The parents complain that sometimes he does not respond when they talk to him. What correctly describes this boy's embryologic defect?
questions.solution:
Treacher Collins syndrome (craniofacial dysostosis) is an autosomal disorder characterized by malar hypoplasia, downward-slanting palpebral fissures, defects of the lower eyelids and external ears, and sometimes abnormalities of the middle and internal ears. Treacher Collins syndrome is a first arch syndrome due to failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the first arch during the fourth week of development.

Other options

  1. Trisomy 13
    • Trisomy 13, also called Patau syndrome, is a chromosomal condition associated with severe intellectual disability and physical abnormalities in many parts of the body including microphthalmia, cleft lip and palate, and brain and spinal cord anomalies.
  2. Defect in FBN1 gene
    • Defect in the fibrillin 1 (FBN1) gene leads to Marfan's syndrome.
  3. Failure of rostral neuropore to close
    • Failure of closure of the rostral neuropore leads to anencephaly.

questions.text: The histopathology specimen from autopsy of a 24-year-old patient is shown in the image below. The given structure is not found in:
questions.solution:
• The marked structure in the given image is cilia.
  • Among the given option epididymis is the only one not having cilia, It is lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia. Motile cilia are located on the epithelial cells of several internal organs such as lungs, trachea, digestive system, etc.

Other options

A. Oviduct (fallopian tube)

C. Bronchi

D. Ependyma

  • Fallopian tube, Bronchi and Ependyma all are lined by ciliated epithelium.

questions.text: Middle radioulnar is type of:
questions.solution:
Middle radioulnar joint is a type of fibrous joint also known as syndesmosis

Other options

A- Plane synovial

B- Primary cartilaginous

C- Secondary cartilaginous

  • Middle radioulnar joint is a type of fibrous joint also known as syndesmosis, therefore Option A, B and C are incorrect answers.

questions.text: Action of muscle at the hip attached to the marked area are:
questions.solution:
• The marked area is Gluteal Tuberosity
  • The muscle inserted to the gluteal tuberosity is Gluteus maximus.

Gluteus maximus

questions.text: Medial lemniscus is formed form:
questions.solution:
• The fibres of fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus Cuneatus terminate in nucleus gracilis and nucleus Cuneatus, respectively.
  • The axons of second-order sensory neurons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus Cuneatus curve ventromedially around the central grey matter of the medulla as internal arcuate fibres to undergo decussation.
  • The fibres after crossing the midline turn upwards as a flat tract called medial lemniscus, which courses upwards to terminate in the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL) of the thalamus.
  • The third-order sensory neurons from thalamus project into the cerebral cortex of the cerebral hemisphere. This pathway carrying conscious proprioceptive sensations is termed 'dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway'.

Other options

  1. Spinothalamic tract
  2. Spinocerebellar
  3. Tectospinal
  • The axons of second-order sensory neurons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus Cuneatus curve ventromedially around the central grey matter of the medulla as internal arcuate fibres to undergo decussation.
  • The fibres after crossing the midline turn upwards as a flat tract called medial lemniscus, which courses upwards to terminate in the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL) of the thalamus, THEREFORE Option B, C and D are incorrect answers.

questions.text: Identify the pyriform fossa in the given Image:
questions.solution:
1. Epiglottis
  2. Pyriform fossa
  3. Ventricular cords (False vocal cords)
  4. Aryepiglottic fold

Pyriform fossa

  • It is a potential space that lies on either side of the larynx. They are two in number. It is shaped like a pyramid with the base point above and the apex below. They belong to the hypopharyngeal area of the pharynx.

It has two parts: the shallow upper part and a deeper lower part.

Boundaries: The pyriform fossa is bounded laterally by the mucosa covering the lamina of the thyroid cartilage. Medially it is bounded by the aryepiglottic fold and arytenoid cartilages above and the cricoid cartilage below. Superiorly it is bounded by the lateral glossoepiglottic fold (Pharyngoepiglottic fold), inferiorly it continues with the oesophagus.

choices.text: Presence of acidophilic serous acini at the tip
Serous acini supported by basal lamina

questions.text: Difference between exocrine pancreas and parotid:
questions.solution:
The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has ONLY the intercalated type

  • The excretory ducts of the parotid gland are STRATIFIED columnar, whereas the excretory duct of the pancreas is SIMPLE columnar
  • The pancreas has ISLETS of LANGERHANS, whereas the parotid does not.

Parotid gland


Other options

B- Presence of acidophilic serous acini at the tip

C- Serous acini supported by basal lamina

D- Apical acinar villi

The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has ONLY the intercalated type

The excretory ducts of the parotid gland are STRATIFIED columnar, whereas the excretory duct of the pancreas is SIMPLE columnar, therefore Option B, C and D are incorrect answers.

Pancreas

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of anterior division of the internal iliac artery?
1.Superior gluteal artery
2.Inferior gluteal artery
3.Superior vesical artery
4.Middle rectal artery
5.Inferior vesical artery
6.Vaginal artery
Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.solution:
The nine branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery may be more easily remembered in these divisions:

  • "Three urinary": umbilical artery, superior vesical artery, inferior vesical artery
  • "Three visceral": uterine artery, vaginal artery, middle rectal artery
  • "Three parietal": obturator artery, internal pudendal artery, inferior gluteal artery.

questions.text:
In a subclavian artery block at the outer border of 1st rib, which of the following arteries help in maintaining the circulation to the upper limb?
1.Suprascapular artery
2.Superior thoracic artery
3.Thyrocervical trunk
4.Subscapular artery
Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.solution:
• A rich anastomosis exists around the scapula between branches of the subclavian artery (first part) and the axillary artery (third part).
  • This anastomosis provides a collateral circulation through which blood can flow to the limb when the distal part of subclavian artery or the proximal part of axillary artery is blocked.

Scapular anastomosis between branches of proximal subclavian and distal axillary artery:

  • Branches of Subclavian artery: Thyrocervical trunk, Suprascapular and Deep branch of Transverse cervical artery.
  • Branches of Axillary artery: Subscapular, Posterior circumflex humeral and Thoracoacromial arteries.

questions.text: Identify the correct diagnosis of the given image of new-born baby.
questions.solution:
• The mucosal surface of posterior wall of the urinary bladder showing ureteric orifices is exposed to the surface.
  • Exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae): In this condition, the lower median part of anterior abdominal wall and anterior wall of the urinary bladder is absent.
  • The urine can be seen dribbling intermittently from the ureteric orifices.

Omphalocele is a ventral body wall defect caused by failure of physiologically herniated loops of bowel to return to the body cavity in the 10-11th week.


  • Omphalocele occurs when abdominal contents herniate through the umbilical ring and persist outside the body covered variably by a translucent peritoneal membrane sac (a light-gray, shiny sac) protruding from the base of the umbilical cord.
  • Omphalocele is a ventral body wall defect caused by failure of physiologically herniated loops of bowel to return to the body cavity in the 10-11th
  • Omphalocele occurs when abdominal contents herniate through the umbilical ring and persist outside the body covered variably by a translucent peritoneal membrane sac (a light-gray, shiny sac) protruding from the base of the umbilical cord.
  • Gastroschisis occurs when there is a defect in the ventral abdominal wall
  • usually to the right of the umbilical ring through which there is a massive
  • evisceration of intestines (other organs may also be involved).
  • The intestines are not covered by a peritoneal membrane, are directly
  • exposed to amniotic fluid and are thickened and covered with adhesions.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with motor vehicle accident presented to causality with fracture of superior pubic ramus and fracture of pubic symphysis. His vitals are stable, but he is unable to pass urine. He has blood at the tip of meatus as shown in the image. What is most, likely the cause of injury.
questions.solution:
The superior ramus of the pubis is above the urogenital diaphragm and will injury membranous urethra.

Rupture of the urethra: The rupture of the urethra leads to extravasation of urine. The commonest site of rupture is bulb of the penis, just below the urogenital diaphragm following a fall astride a sharp object. The urethra is crushed against the edge of the pubic bones.

The urine extravasates into the superficial perineal pouch and passes forward over the scrotum, penis, and anterior part of the anterior abdominal wall deep to membranous layer of the superficial fascia (superficial extravasation).

If the urethra ruptures above urogenital diaphragm urine escapes above the deep perineal pouch and may pass upward around the prostate and bladder in the extraperitoneal space (deep extravasation).

questions.text: Which of the following structure are involved for condition shown in image.
questions.solution:
The above image is of Peaud'orange sign. The peau d'orange sign, which is an orange peel-like appearance of the breast, can be caused by the suspensory ligaments of Cooper. These ligaments are made of connective tissue and support the breast by extending from the skin to the deep fascia.

In breast cancer, the ligaments can contract, which can cause the breast to become rigid and the skin to pucker. The ligaments can also shorten, which can lead to dimpling.

The peau d'orange sign occurs when the lymphatic ducts become blocked, which causes swelling and edema in the breast. The skin remains tethered by the ligaments, resulting in the dimpled appearance.

questions.text: A patient suffered from stroke previously has now presented with sudden onset of flailing arm Ballistic movement. What is the site of location.
questions.solution: A lesion in the contralateral sub-thalamic nucleus of the basal ganglia, results in the appearance of flailing, ballistic, undesired movements of the limbs. Hemiballismus as a result of stroke occurs in only about 0.45 cases per hundred thousand stroke victims

questions.text: Muscle attached to the arrow marked bony structure is
questions.solution:
• Marked structure in the image is the lesser trochanter of the femur. The iliacus and psoas muscles fuse to form the iliopsoas muscle which passes anterior to the hip joint and is inserted onto the lesser trochanter of the femur.

The iliacus arises from the iliac fossa on the interior side of the hip bone, and also from the region of the anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS). It joins the psoas major to form the iliopsoas.

It proceeds across the iliopubic eminence through the muscular lacuna to its insertion on the lesser trochanter of the femur. Its fibers are often inserted in front of those of the psoas major and extend distally over the lesser trochanter.

Other options

  • Option B: Gluteus maximus originates from the gluteal surface of ilium, and has two insertion points. Superficial fibres to the greater trochanter and a band of the fascia lata and the deep fibres that insert into the gluteal tuberosity between the adductor magnus and vastus lateralis
  • Option C: Gluteus medius originates from the gluteal surface of ilium, under gluteus maximus and is inserted to the lateral aspect of the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • Option D: Sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and is inserted onto the proximal end of tibia below medial condyle via pes anserinus.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures represent merocrine gland?
questions.solution:
Here,

  • A- Sebaceous (holocrine)
  • B- Merocrine
  • C- Root of hair follicle
  • D- Adipose tissue

1. Merocrine (eccrine gland):

  • No loss of any cell membrane
  • Secretory vesicles fuse with the apical plasma membrane to release their products into a duct (e.g. secretion of saliva by salivary glands).
  • Seen in parotid gland, salivary gland.

2. Apocrine gland :

  • Mammary gland (modified sweat gland)
  • secretory products are released at the apical cell surface in small membrane bound vesicles that enter into a duct (e.g. secretion of lipid droplets in the mammary gland).
  • There is apical loss of cell membrane
  • Axilla, perineum, ceruminous gland

3.Holocrine :

  • Sebaceous gland in skin
  • Entire cell membrane is lost, cells are broken and organelles become contents of secretion like sebum and goes along hair follicle
  • Lipids are extracted during tissue processing, resulting in pale staining within the secretory cells.
